name: 鄭以旋
objective: This course introduces concepts related to commerce, business and economics such as money, capitalism(s), technology, and sustainability. Students are required to read canonical and key modern texts on these topics, as well as current business news and analytic articles. In addition, expert senior professional guest speaker(s) will familiarize students with current business practices.

scorePolicy:
Evaluation 

Group presentation			20%
Mid-term				30%		
Final exam				30%
Participation and attendance		20%

At the lecturer’s sole discretion, a makeup mid-term or exam may be granted upon presentation of a note of approval for leave from the university system no later than 5 days after the date of the mid-term or exam. The format of the make-up will be determined by the lecturer.

Attendance policy
You will automatically receive a grade of zero with 8 or more unexcused absences from Week 2 onwards. You may get an excused absence only upon presentation of a note of approval for leave from the university system.
materials:
Excerpts from the following (to be finalized)

Money:
•	Ha-Joon Chang, Economics: The User’s Guide, 2014.
•	Georg Simmel, The Philosophy of Money, 1978.
•	Nigel Dodd, The Social Life of Money, 2014.
•	Adam Smith, Selections from The Wealth of Nations, 1957.

Capitalisms:
•	Nick Srnicek, Platform Capitalism, 2016.
•	Shoshana Zuboff, The Age of Surveillance Capitalism, 2019.
•	David Harvey, A Brief History of Neoliberalism, 2005.
•	Thomas Piketty, Capital in the Twenty-first Century, 2013.

Alternative systems:
•	John Ruskin, selected writings.
•	Karl Marx, selected writings.
•	Evgeny Morozov, “Critique of Techno-Feudal Reason,” New Left Review, 133/134, Jan/Apr 2022.

Business ethics:
•	Nigel Dodd, “The Politics of Bitcoin,” Money in Human Economy, Berghahn Books, 2017.
•	Thomas Piketty, A Brief History of Inequality, 2022.
•	Michael Sandel, What Money Can’t Buy: The Moral Limits of Markets, 2012.
